title: Torque and alpha - 2 rods L0 and 2L0 - same force

content.question: A uniform rod of length <math alttext="L sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> is free to rotate about an axis through its left end and perpendicular to the horizontal plane of the figure shown. When a force with magnitude <math alttext="F sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> is exerted perpendicular to the rod at the right end, the angular acceleration of the rod is <math alttext="alpha sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. The same force is then exerted on the right end of a second uniform rod with the same linear mass density and twice the length as the original rod, as shown on the right side of the figure. The rod of length <math alttext="2 L sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> has an angular acceleration <math alttext="alpha sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. What is the ratio <math alttext="ratio of alpha sub 2 to alpha sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math> ?
